summary: This document is an email chain from August 11, 2019, discussing the Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) suicide watch protocol. It includes an explanation from a Psychology Services Administrator about the purpose, conditions, and typical duration of suicide watch as a short-term crisis intervention, sent in response to a query from the Office of the Attorney General (OAG).

persons.name: Psychology Services Administrator
persons.context: The individual who provided the detailed explanation of the BOP's suicide watch protocol, including its purpose, conditions, and assessment procedures.

events.title: Email Correspondence on Suicide Watch Protocol
events.description: An email exchange occurs where a BOP Psychology Services Administrator provides a detailed explanation of suicide watch procedures to the Office of the Attorney General (OAG).

keyFacts: The document is an email from August 11, 2019, explaining the Bureau of Prisons' suicide watch protocol.
Suicide watch is described as a highly restrictive, short-term crisis intervention focused on immediate suicide prevention, not long-term quality of life.
Conditions include constant observation, a special smock, a stripped cell, 24-hour lighting, and limited personal property.
A doctoral-level psychologist assesses when an inmate is no longer an immediate threat to themselves to end suicide watch.
The explanation was provided in response to a query from the Office of the Attorney General (OAG) regarding the impact of prolonged suicide watch.
